newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX Hub natgas ends down, longs bail on cash.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX Hub natgas ends down, longs bail on cash.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures ended down sharply Thursday in an active session, with a bearish inventory report and more moderate weekend weather forecasts undermining cash and paper prices, sources said.
July expired 8.2 cents lower at $2.145 per million British thermal units. August slumped nine cents to close at $2.123. Other deferreds ended down by 1.7 to 9.3 cents.

"(Bearish) AGAs, no additional weather and some nukes coming back all pressured the market. Then when July couln't hold above unchanged, it killed it," said one Midwest trader, adding an August close below $2.105 would be very bearish.
PECO said it expected its 1,055 MW Limerick 1 nuke unit in Pennsylvania, shut last weekend due to a leaking valve, to be back on line Friday.
Most agreed Wednesday's unexpectedly-large 97 bcf weekly AGA stock build coupled with late-week forecasts for more seasonal Northeast weather set the stage for long liquidation.
Weather in Texas and the Southwest was expected to drift around normal, while heat was expected to persist in the Midwest.

Chart traders pegged August support along the up trendline at $2.105, with more buying expected at the recent $2.08 low. Trendline resistance was seen at $2.27, with further selling likely at the recent $2.36 high and then at the $2.415 contract high.

In the cash Thursday, June Gulf Coast gas tumbled almost 10 cents to about the $2.20 area, with July on the same pipes pegged in the mid-teens. June Midcon lost a similar amount to the low-$2s. New York city gate gas was quoted in the low-$2.50s, down from the $2.60s Wednesday.
The NYMEX 12-month Henry Hub strip skidded 6.3 cents to $2.208. NYMEX said 94,197 contracts traded, up sharply from Wednesday's revised tally of 65,527.

On the KCBT, August finished eight lower at $2.00, while deferreds ended down by 4.5 to 7.5 cents. The August East/West spread narrowed by one cent to 12.3 cents (NYMEX premium). KCBT said 249 lots traded, down sharply from Wednesday's total of 1,256.
